html.p: DJU are the Dubh Java Utilities. While writing NewsAgent, I realised that vast amounts of code could potentially be usable by other projects. To this end, I tried to keep common code separate from the rest of NewsAgent by putting it in the dju package space. The Dubh Java Utilities are the end result.

You are welcome to use the DJU in your own projects. You simply need to download the DJU jar file and make sure it's in the CLASSPATH of your java runtime. Before you do this, you should look at the license for DJU to make sure you are complying with its terms. More information on the license for DJU is available below.

DJU has not yet been formally released as a separate product. The only release so far has been as part of NewsAgent 1.0 and 1.02. Both these releases were licenced under the GNU General Public License, and no licensing information was available separately for DJU.

GNU GPL doesn't work very well for libraries of common code like DJU. There is a separate GNU license for library code, called the LGPL (Library or Lesser General Public License). However, Richard Stallman seems to be recommending that even libraries use GPL these days.

An unfortunate consequence of using the GPL is that, even though it is an open source license (and therefore fundamentally less restrictive than most commercial software licenses), it nevertheless places a restriction on using the licensed software in what it calls "derived products". Derived products must also carry the GPL license, which in effect, makes GPL viral - if you want to use a library licensed under GPL in your software, you have to license your software under GPL.

This to me seems far too restrictive, and could potentially limit the use of the DJU library. For that reason, I'm still considering possible licenses for DJU. My current favourite is the MPL (Mozilla Public License), as used by the Mozilla project.
